'''Richard Decker''', (May 6, 1907 – November 1, 1988)<ref name="books.google.co.in">[https://books.google.com/books?id=OncYAAAAIAAJ&dq=cartoonist+richard+decker&ei=fZtUSsyJOImskgSdxK2zBw The World encyclopedia of cartoons By Maurice Horn, Richard Marschall, 1980 Page 191]</ref> a cartoonist and illustrator, studied at the Pennsylvania School of Industrial Art<ref name="books.google.co.in"/> and became famous for his cartoons published in [[The New Yorker]].<ref>[http://www.cartoonbank.com/search_results_category.asp?sitetype=1&section=all&keyword=Richard+Decker&advanced=0&x=15&y=10 Richard Decker's Work from The New Yorker]</ref>
==Works== Decker worked almost 40 years as a contract cartoonist for the New Yorker. He started out in 1929 with the magazine and then eventually worked his way up to becoming well-known on the New Yorker's pages for cartoons. Decker's humor covers a broad spectrum from changing times to even his large family. Decker's work in ink and watercolor had been featured in several area exhibitions.<ref name="Richard Decker">{{cite web|last=St. George|first=Donna|title=Richard Fulmer Decker, 81, Artist; Drew Famous Bulletin Ad Cartoons|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-11-04/news/26247868_1_cartoons-new-yorker-berwyn|publisher=The Inquirer|accessdate=28 December 2012}}</ref> He did illustrations for "Look" and the "Saturday Evening Post"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=BdRVSvvWComskgTWw7SiBA&id=i__VAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22richard+decker%22+Saturday+Evening+Post&q=%22richard+decker%22+Saturday+Evening+Post The art of the New Yorker, 1925-1995 By Lee Lorenz]</ref> and did a number of advertisements for the "Philadelphia Evening Bulletin".<ref name="Richard Decker" /><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=8Z1USt73NJL4lQSqtsGpBw&id=yXVQAAAAMAAJ&dq=cartoonist+richard+decker&q=richard+decker Cartooning By Roy Paul Nelson, 1975 Page:38] and [https://books.google.com/books?ei=8Z1USt73NJL4lQSqtsGpBw&id=97JPAAAAMAAJ&dq=cartoonist+richard+decker&q=richard+decker The design of advertising By Roy Paul Nelson, 1977 Page:58]</ref>
==Recognition== [[Ben Yagoda]] has called Decker, along with Robert J. Day, "underrecognized New Yorker masters."<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Yagoda |authorlink=Ben Yagoda |title=Laughter in the Dark |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/books/review/Yagoda.t.html?ei=5070&en=c26f5aee190b3386&ex=1188014400&pagewanted=all |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2006-12-03 |accessdate=2008-12-08}}</ref>
==Death== Decker died in November 1988 at Cathcart Health Care Center in [[Devon, Pennsylvania]]. He was a resident of [[Berwyn, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Richard Decker" />
